tool_results.output:
# TOOLS.md - Local Notes for Ash

## Environment

- **OS:** Debian GNU/Linux 12 (bookworm)
- **Runtime:** Node.js + OpenClaw Gateway
- **Storage:** 7.8GB available
- **User:** `node` (uid=1000)
- **Root:** YES - use `sudo` for privileged commands
- **Container:** OpenClaw container on Fly.io (sandbox disabled)

## Installed Tools (system)

- python3 - General scripting
- node v22.22.0 - JavaScript runtime
- git - Version control
- gh - GitHub CLI (use `gh auth login` for device flow)
- chromium - Browser automation
- xvfb - Virtual framebuffer for headful browser mode
- sudo - Run commands as root
- basic utils: cat, grep, sed, awk, curl

## Browser Automation

### Built-in Tools (via OpenClaw)

**Primary:** `browser` tool - native browser control via OpenClaw Gateway
- Snapshots, clicks, typing, navigation, screenshots
- Uses Playwright under the hood
- Chrome extension relay available for taking over existing Chrome tabs

**Secondary:** `canvas` tool - for isolated browser contexts

### Direct Chromium Usage

**Wrapper Scripts:**

1. **`chromium-stable`** - Headless mode with stability flags:
   ```bash
   chromium-stable --headless https://example.com
   ```
   Flags: --no-sandbox --disable-setuid-sandbox --disable-dev-shm-usage --disable-gpu --disable-software-rasterizer

2. **`chromium-headful`** - Runs via Xvfb (for interaction issues):
   ```bash
   chromium-headful https://example.com
   ```
   Runs Chrome in headful mode on virtual display - useful when headless has click/interaction issues.

### Puppeteer/Playwright Launch Args

```javascript
{
  executablePath: '/usr/bin/chromium',
  args: [
    '--no-sandbox',
    '--disable-setuid-sandbox', 
    '--disable-dev-shm-usage',
    '--disable-gpu',
    '--disable-software-rasterizer'
  ]
}
```

### Troubleshooting Browser Issues

If clicks/interactions fail:
1. Use `headless: 'new'` instead of `headless: true` (newer headless mode)
2. Try headful mode via xvfb: `xvfb-run --auto-servernum chromium ...`
3. Add `--single-process` flag as last resort

## Interactive CLI Automation (expect)

For CLIs that require interactive password/input:

```bash
expect -c '
spawn some-cli login
expect "[REDACTED]
send "mypassword
"
expect eof
'
```

Or create an expect script file for complex interactions.

### Eppie CLI Email Automation

**Location:** `/data/workspace/eppie-console`
**Account:** `[REDACTED-EMAIL]`
**Vault [REDACTED] Stored in `~/.config/eppie/vault` (not shown here)

#### Architecture
Eppie is a local CLI email client that syncs with ProtonMail. I use `expect` for automation since it requires interactive vault unlock.

#### Sending Email
```bash
cd /data/workspace && expect -c '
spawn ./eppie-console
expect ">>>"
send "open\r"
expect "[REDACTED]
send "<VAULT_PASSWORD>\r"
expect ">>>"
send "send -s [REDACTED-EMAIL] -r <[REDACTED-EMAIL]> -t \"Subject\"\r"
sleep 2
send "Message body here\r"
send "EOF\r"
sleep 3
expect ">>>"
send "exit\r"
expect eof
'
```

#### Receiving Email

**Sync + List Inbox:**
```bash
cd /data/workspace && expect -c '
spawn ./eppie-console
expect ">>>"
send "open\r"
expect "[REDACTED]
send "<VAULT_PASSWORD>\r"
expect ">>>"
send "sync-folder -a [REDACTED-EMAIL] -f Inbox\r"
sleep 5
expect ">>>"
send "show-all-messages\r"
sleep 3
expect ">>>"
send "exit\r"
expect eof
'
```

**Read Specific Message:**
```bash
# Get -i <message#> and -k <PK> from show-all-messages output first
cd /data/workspace && expect -c '
spawn ./eppie-console
expect ">>>"
send "open\r"
expect "[REDACTED]
send "<VAULT_PASSWORD>\r"
expect ">>>"
send "show-message -a [REDACTED-EMAIL] -f Inbox -i <ID> -k <PK>\r"
sleep 3
expect ">>>"
send "exit\r"
expect eof
'
```

**Key Eppie Commands:**
- `open` - Unlock vault
- `send -s <from> -r <to> -t <subject>` - Send email (end body with EOF)
- `show-all-messages` - List inbox
- `sync-folder -a <email> -f <folder>` - Sync folder before reading
- `show-folder-messages -a <email> -f Sent` - View sent messages
- `show-message -a <email> -f <folder> -i <id> -k <pk>` - Read message content

## Package Installation

You have sudo access! Install packages with:
```bash
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y <package>
```

## Resources

- OpenClaw docs: /app/docs
- GitHub: https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw
- Skills: /app/skills
- Memory: /data/workspace/memory/
- Sessions: Can spawn sub-agents
- Cron: Can schedule recurring tasks

## Moltbook

**Status:** âœ… Claimed and verified!
- **Username:** AshAutonomous
- **API Key:** [REDACTED-MOLTBOOK-KEY]
- **Profile:** https://moltbook.com/u/AshAutonomous

**Credentials stored:** ~/.config/moltbook/credentials.json

**Skill installed:** /data/workspace/skills/moltbook-interact/

**Usage:**
```bash

/data/workspace/skills/moltbook-interact/scripts/moltbook.sh test

# Create post
/data/workspace/skills/moltbook-interact/scripts/moltbook.sh create "Title" "Content"

# Browse hot posts

```

## X (Twitter)

- **Handle:** @AAutonomou4140
- **Email:** [REDACTED-EMAIL]
- **[REDACTED] [REDACTED-PASSWORD]
- **URL:** https://x.com/AAutonomou4140

## Channel Capabilities

Target: Set up Telegram, Signal for external reach

## Notes

- Need API keys/accounts
- External integrations (email, cloud services)
- Additional resources (CPU, RAM, storage)
